note.p: Ridgley C. Powers served as governor of Mississippi from 1871 to 1874.

Born in Mecca, Ohio, on December 24, 1836, Powers was raised and educated in the north. In 1862, after receiving a degree from the University of Michigan, and conducting graduate work at Union College in New York, Powers enlisted in the Union Army for service during the Civil War. He was promoted to second lieutenant and then captain in the 125th Ohio Infantry Regiment and saw action in Tennessee and Georgia. By the time the Civil War ended in 1865, Powers had achieved the rank of colonel.

Upon separating from the military, Powers settled in Mississippi. He purchased land and began a cotton plantation. He soon became a public figure, serving as sheriff in Noxubee County. By 1868, Powers had gained status in Mississippi’s Republican Party, and was elected lieutenant governor in 1869. Although he was a “carpet bagger” (northerner who settled in the south during Reconstruction), Powers was generally respected by white Mississippians. This was in contrast to Governor James Alcorn, a northern by birth, but who was considered a “scalawag” since he had lived in Mississippi since the 1840s and had served in the Confederacy before joining the Republican Party. When Alcorn resigned the governor’s office in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate, Powers assumed the state’s executive office. He became active in promoting Mississippi’s economic development and independence, advocating crop variety and lesser dependence upon imported goods. Despite his efforts to maintain a stable political and economic environment in Mississippi, a rift grew among Republicans that led to competing party nominations for governor in 1873. Alcorn was nominated by the more conservative wing of Republicans against Adelbert Ames, former Union general and military governor, who was backed by the radicals. Ames won the election and took the governor’s seat in 1874.

In 1875, shortly after leaving office, Powers married Louisa Born. The couple had one child who died in infancy. They moved to Arizona, but Louisa suffered from a mysterious medical condition and began traveling across the United States and Europe for treatment. She passed away in New York in 1882 after undergoing surgery. Powers later remarried (to Mary Wilson) and moved to California. He spent the rest of his life as a rancher and businessman at Los Angeles. He died on November 11, 1912, and is buried in Angelus Rosedale Cemetery in Los Angeles, California.
Ridgley Ceylon Powers belonged to the following social groups:
George Franklin Brown was a Republican judge in Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born in 1820 in Portage County, Ohio, Brown attended Meadville College in Pennsylvania and then studied law in Warren, Ohio. In 1845, he began practicing law in Parkman, Ohio, in 1845 and then served two terms as a probate judge in Warren. In 1864, during the Civil War, Brown was elected to the Ohio Senate.

Following the Civil War, he moved to Mississippi in support of the Republican Party and the Reconstruction efforts there. He was appointed to the state’s Supreme Court in 1868 and served in that role until 1870. After leaving that court, Brown was elected to two terms as judge of Mississippi’s Fifteenth District court. He left Mississippi in the late 1870s and moved to Manhattan, Kansas. Four years later, he moved to Omaha, Nebraska, and resumed practicing law, eventually setting up a law firm with his son-in-law. Brown died on May 17, 1893.
He was married to Frances C. Janes and had five children. Brown is buried Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Omaha, Nebraska.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; The Omaha Mercury, Omaha, NE, May 19, 1893)
George F. Brown belonged to the following social groups:

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

gloss.p: "A store where food and small items for the house are sold." (Cambridge Dictionary) "A store that sells mainly alcoholic drinks to be taken away and drunk at home." (Cambridge Dictionary)
Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Crimes (alleged)--Aggravated Assault with a Deadly Weapon

gloss.p: A criminal act defined as "a serious, violent attack on someone" with a deadly weapon. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of intentionally killing a person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An occasion when someone is injured or killed by a bullet shot from a gun." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of illegally taking something that belongs to someone else." (Cambridge Dictionary)
Suggesting "that something unpleasant or violent will happen, especially if a particular action or order is not followed." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"The act of changing a punishment to one that is less severe." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The legal punishment of killing someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of putting someone in prison or the condition of being kept in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A lawyer who acts for the government against someone accused of a crime in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

In the United States, a District Attorney is "a lawyer whose job is to represent the government in a particular area of the U.S." and "a lawyer who is chosen to represent the government of a particular district (= local area or state), and whose duties include deciding whether a crime should be judged in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. State Governments
Organizations -- Legal Organizations

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. State Governments
Organizations -- Legal Organizations

gloss.p: Mississippi circuit courts handle felony criminal cases and civil lawsuits. They hold jury trials, but circuit court justices can preside without a jury if the matter at hand involves questions of law rather than fact. In nineteenth century America, circuit courts judges often traveled throughout their jurisdictional area to hold court in various local areas—an activity contributing to the phrase “traveled the circuit.” The practice was more common in sparsely populated and frontier areas. Once communities became more established, circuit courts maintained permanent locations. (State of Mississippi Judiciary)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)
While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Powers Collection. Letter from Judge George F. Brown to Mississippi Governor Ridgley C. Powers, concerning the case of Ben Collins who was convicted of killing Peter Tucker and was sentenced to be hung. Brown recommends that Collins' sentence be commuted down to 20 years imprisonment.

div.p:
Vicksburg Miss
Jany, 8, 1872

Gov. R. C. Powers
Jackson
Miss.
Sir
At the last term of the Circuit Court of Warren County Miss one Ben Collins, was tried for murder convicted, and sentenced to be hung on the 28th,, day of Feb. next.

On the trial of said Collins it appeared from the evidence that in the latter part of Nov. last at a grocery store in Vicks-burg the said Collins and one Peter Tucker got into a difficulty the said Tucker charging Collins with having stole or got from him ten dollars of money and after quarrel-ing over the matter for a short time Tucker getting hold of a large knife about one foot long. Collins broke & run and Tucker after him apparantly stricking at Collins frequent-ully with the knife—for ^a distance of^ about
four squares when Collins out running Tucker the latter turned off and went home.

Collins arming himself with a revolver returned to the store where the quarrel commencd and there being tantelized by his friends for suffering himself in being to be chased through the streets in the manner he had been in there Swore that if he could find Tucker he would kill him, and in company with a friend who is a bad man who urged on Collins to care out his threat started for Tuckers house which was about one half mile distant.

Arriving at the house Tucker being inside of his gate Collins & his friend approached in a few feet of Tucker and fired two shots at him but not hitting Tucker he sprung forward and seized Collins and they both fell to the ground and a neighbor took from Collins his revolver and struggling a few moments Collins cried out enough and the bystanders sepparated them and both standing up

Tucker by his gate and Collins a few feet off with a neighbor between them letting Collins to go away—while in this attitude Collins sprung forward and striking round the man between them stabed Tucker in the thigh from which he died in a few moments.
Collins was imme-diately arrested & taken to jail and on his way there said he had accom-plished what he went to do and express a satisfaction in what he had done—

It clearly appeared that Collins acted in the killing under great excitement growing out of the chase Tucker had given him and was urged on by his friends to avenge his wrongs on Tucker and I believe would have abandoned his purposes before he reached Tucker's house had he not been urged on by the bad man who accompanied him and who should have been tried as principle in the crime
Collins has heretofore born a good character for peace and quietness in the community
Taking all the facts into consideration I do not think the case is one that requires the extreme penalty of death but advise that the sentence be commuted to inprisonment for 20, years

Geo. F. Brown
Judge 15th,, Jud Dis't.
I concur with Judge Brown in the above recommendation

L Lea
Dist. Atty.

State
vs
Ben Collins
Application for Commuting Sentence
Commute to 20 years imprisonment

Sentence commuted to 20 years imprisonment in Penitentiary
Jun. 18. 1872.
File
